Aug 7, 2016

Finding the debt effect

We knew household debt was a risk to the UK’s financial stability. Now, a new report suggests excess debt can have deeper effects, limiting people’s life chances

When the Bank of England cut interest rates last Thursday, household debt was no more than a background note to concerns about growth. Its solo had come earlier in July when, in the Bank’s Financial Stability report, Mark Carney had given his starkest warning yet about the UK’s high levels of personal debt. Some households, Carney said, simply wouldn’t make it through a new downturn while others, worried that they might default, would cut back deeply on spending, exacerbating any wider slowdown.

But while it’s the Bank’s job to worry about the destabilising effects of debt, there are also reasons for government policymakers to be concerned. As a new report from Citizens Advice reveals, excessive levels of personal debt can corrode everything from mental health to people’s attitudes to risk. And it’s these more corrosive effects that could prompt the UK’s new government to make support for the most indebted households a key plank of a more inclusive economic and social policy.

To understand debt’s deeper effects it’s useful to start with the opposite: the effect that savings have on people’s lives.

Since around the mid-1990s there’s been strong evidence of the positive effect that savings can have. The so-called ‘asset effect’ tells us that savings improve people’s life chances even independent of other factors. Take two people with the same income, age, and gender, and the person with more savings does better in life.

To policymakers at the time, these findings suggested that savings provide a kind of springboard, letting people invest in things like training, and also a safety net, giving people enough reassurance to take calculated risks. They prompted the incoming 1997 government to develop a suite of policies to help people save, from the Child Trust Fund to the Savings Gateway.

This all raises an obvious question: can excessive debt have a similar but opposite effect, holding people back? And, if so, should this prompt a new set of measures to help those households that are deepest in debt?

Today’s new report tackles this question from three angles. First, our researchers worked with the Institute for Social and Economic Research to compare the lives of people with excess debt to those without, using data from the Understanding Society survey to isolate debt’s effects. Second, they looked at data from the 350,000 people Citizens Advice helps each year with problem debt, exploring how debt links to other problems in people’s lives. Third, the report surveys people with particularly high levels of debt, teasing out debt’s effects on people’s attitudes and behaviours — focusing, in particular, on their approach to risk.

Before jumping into the findings, let’s define problem debt. There’s no perfect way to do this so the report uses a reasonable measure of people who have unsecured debts worth more than six months’ income. This defines someone with an income of £30,000, for example, as being in trouble when their debt passes £15,000 — and remember we’re only talking about unsecured debts, from credit cards to personal loans, and not mortgages.

It turns out that one in 20 adults in the UK (5%) have unsecured debts of this level — and in some groups this figure is much higher:

  • 14% of 20–29 year olds have unsecured debts worth more than six months’ income, twice the figure for 30–39 year olds and nearly three times the national average
  • 7% of the lowest paid fifth of the population have unsecured debt worth more than six month’s income; one and a half times the proportion in the overall population
  • 10% of private renters have unsecured debts worth six months of their income, nearly twice the proportion among people with a mortgage

So what effect does this debt have? When you crunch the numbers, and isolate debt from other factors, the most striking result is the link between debt and poor mental health. People with problematic levels of debt are 24 per cent more likely to have poor mental health (having a mental health score in the bottom quarter of the population) even controlling for income and other factors. Cut another way, people with below average mental health scores are twice as likely to be behind on a household bill. These are striking effects and are reason enough to worry about the level and distribution of household debt in the UK.

One explanation for this link between debt and poor mental health comes from the second area the report explores: Citizens Advice’s own data. Of the 350,000 people we helped with a debt problem last year, more than half (54%) also had a problem in another aspect of their lives, on issues ranging from relationships to employment to housing. You can think of this as debt’s tangle factor, showing how intertwined debt is with other issues. The equivalent figures for problems related to housing, benefits, relationships and employment are 47%, 47%, 44%, and 37% respectively. So people get more tangled up in debt problems than they do in other issues.

The graphic below shows this clearly, visualising the links between the issues faced by people who came to Citizens Advice for face to face advice. (This focuses on our face to face advice; the breakdowns for the advice we provide over the phone and through digital channels are different.) The thicker the line, the stronger the link. Little wonder three quarters of our debt clients say their debts made them anxious or stressed.

The link between debt and other problems in people’s lives

But perhaps the most interesting finding is the effect excess debt can have on behaviours and attitudes. Our polling confirms what you might guess: just as savings give people the confidence to take calculated risks, so debt does the opposite, weighing heavily on the mind and holding people back.

The report finds that 27% of people with manageable levels of debt say their debt makes them less likely to study or retrain and this jumps to 41% among people with very high levels of debt. More strikingly, 49% of people with very high levels of debt say their debt makes them less likely to start a business. Similar patterns emerge for moving jobs and moving home.

This is not to say these are bad decisions. But it does show how debt can be hard to escape, inhibiting precisely the kinds of calculated risk-taking — a new job, a new town, a new business — that might provide a route out for the individual, and that are a source of dynamism and mobility in society at large.

The impact of debt on people’s decision making, % of respondents by markers of excess debt

So what should we conclude? Certainly not that all debt is bad. On the contrary, borrowing can be a powerful positive force, supporting just these kinds of life decisions, such as retraining, or simply helping to smooth out the bumps of life. Nor, of course, would the government want to fall into the trap of encouraging people to pay down their debts on mass. After all, we’ve been there before and, with consumer confidence now fragile at best, this is hardly the time for such a message.

But, within these constraints, there are real opportunities for an incoming administration to do more to help the households that are struggling the most. By way of example, here are three practical things the new government could do to reduce the harmful effects that result when debt spirals out of control.

One, the government could make it easier for people to lift themselves out of problem debt. As things stand in England, Debt Management Plans — agreements people reach with their creditors to pay off their debts over a set period — have no legal basis. This means creditors can renege on the agreement partway through, meaning that, even when a person shows both the will and the means to pay down their debts, and a deal is reached, the risk stays hanging over their heads. Putting these plans on a legal footing, as other countries have done, could help the most heavily indebted households find a way out. And, by giving people more peace of mind, it could also reduce those attitudinal effects, making households less flighty and more able to move ahead with their lives.

Two, the steepest debt spirals can be stopped or made shallower with protections against the worst lending practices. The chart below shows how Citizens Advice saw problems with payday lenders surge in late 2013/14 before we worked with the Financial Conduct Authority to bring an end the 5,000% interest rates that were landing so many people in trouble. Since these new protections came in, problems have halved, while the wider payday loan market continues in a safer form.

Meanwhile, other exploitative practices persist. For example, Logbook Loans are a Victorian debt contract, first used to borrow against steam engines and now being used to lend money secured against cars. These are woefully uneven debt contracts, allowing the lender to repossess without warning — we saw one client who was literally left at the side of the road as her car was driven away. These contracts could be reformed or even abolished without any risk to the wider availability of credit.

Number of problems Citizens Advice see with payday loans, number of issues reported per quarter

Three, there should of course be greater efforts to prevent debt problems before they occur. This means building on the last government’s work to promote a savings culture. We welcomed the government’s decision to direct more of the funding for money advice to frontline services where it’s so sorely needed, a move that could free up significant sums for additional preventative support. Resources like these can fund much-needed efforts, for example through interventions at key life stages such as having a first child, or when people seek help on other issues, when we know they are receptive to support.

James Plunkett is Director of Policy & Advocacy at Citizens Advice, an organisation providing free, independent, and confidential advice to help people find a way forward.
